newsitem.title: JAPAN: U.S. Treasuries supported in Tokyo, ignore dollar.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasuries supported in Tokyo, ignore dollar.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries were well-supported at the Tokyo midday on Wednesday due to light short-covering following recent falls, traders said.
The market so far has ignored the dollar's steep fall against the yen this morning, they said.
Longer-end Treasuries were particularly well-supported, but activity was thin due to a lack of incentives as traders waited for Thursday's U.S. retail sales and Friday's producer price index data.
The 6-5/8 percent 30-year bond stood at 97-10/32, yielding 6.84 percent, compared with 97-8/32 in New York on Tuesday.
A U.S. brokerage manager said the shorter end of the market was starting to discount another credit tightening, and such speculation kept prices supported.
The September T-bond futures contract stood at 110-16/32, down 1/32 from the previous close.
Treasuries fell for two consecutive days in overseas markets, mainly because of downward corrections.
Traders said talk of Asian central bank purchases of five- and 10-year notes also supported the market.
"Many major Japanese investors are waiting for the dollar to stabilise," another trader said.
